name: Date & Gorgonzola Stuffed Sweet Potatoes
description: These Date & Gorgonzola Stuffed Sweet Potatoes are a simple way to make a big impression. These potatoes are dressed to impress.

recipeInstructions.text: Preheat the oven to 400 degrees. Wash the sweet potatoes and then dry the excess water from the skin with a paper towel or clean dish cloth. Rub the olive oil all over the surface of the sweet potatoes. Use a fork to prick each potato several times.
recipeInstructions.name: Preheat the oven to 400 degrees. Wash the sweet potatoes and then dry the excess water from the skin with a paper towel or clean dish cloth. Rub the olive oil all over the surface of the sweet potatoes. Use a fork to prick each potato several times.

recipeInstructions.text: Cover a baking sheet with foil and then place the potatoes on top. Bake the sweet potatoes for 45 minutes to one hour, or until they are soft all the way through (squeeze the potatoes to test for doneness).
recipeInstructions.name: Cover a baking sheet with foil and then place the potatoes on top. Bake the sweet potatoes for 45 minutes to one hour, or until they are soft all the way through (squeeze the potatoes to test for doneness).

recipeInstructions.text: Allow the sweet potatoes to rest for a few minutes while you prepare the filling. Roughly chop the dates and parsley (and the walnuts, if not purchased pre-chopped). Mix the dates, walnuts, and parsley together.
recipeInstructions.name: Allow the sweet potatoes to rest for a few minutes while you prepare the filling. Roughly chop the dates and parsley (and the walnuts, if not purchased pre-chopped). Mix the dates, walnuts, and parsley together.

recipeInstructions.text: Once the sweet potatoes are cool enough to handle, slice them from one end to the other, lengthwise. Pinch each end and push in towards the center to make the potato pop open. Mash the inside up a bit with a fork, then stuff with the date/walnut filling. Sprinkle 1 tablespoon of gorgonzola on each potato. Serve warm.
recipeInstructions.name: Once the sweet potatoes are cool enough to handle, slice them from one end to the other, lengthwise. Pinch each end and push in towards the center to make the potato pop open. Mash the inside up a bit with a fork, then stuff with the date/walnut filling. Sprinkle 1 tablespoon of gorgonzola on each potato. Serve warm.

review.reviewBody: I was a bit skeptical of this, but I've loved almost every single recipe that I've tried here, so I gave it a go and the results were delicious. I didn't use the parsley (it basically tastes like grass clippings to me), and toasted the walnuts in the oven for about 6 minutes for extra crunch.
A delicious little vegetarian meal! I will definitely repeat again, and want to try goat cheese next time. Thanks for another great one Beth!

These were great! I couldn't find gorgonzola at the store, so I used feta instead (which turned out to be a good thing once I realized gorgonzola is similar to blue cheese!) We found leftovers were great as a sweet and yummy breakfast the next morning.

I loved the combination of all the flavors. I did add bacon since I planned on eating it as a dinner by itself. The only thing was that I found it to be extremely filling...I could only eat half. I can't imagine this as a side dish. 

Also...now I have a whole container of the dates and I'm not sure what else to do with them. Any suggestions?
These were excellent, with a beautiful sweet-salty-creamy-crunchy balance. I was skeptical about whether I'd like sweet potatoes with no butter, but these didn't need anything else.

Had them for dinner last night - holy moly! Incredibly delicious! We stuck to the receipe, but baked the sweet potatoes at a lower temperature for longer to let it caramelize a bit more, then added all the goodies. Unbelievable! Instant favorite.
What a fantastic idea! I will be cooking some kale and throwing that in to see if it plays well with the flavors-- just to add a green veggie. Yum!
